Funds raised will support this wonderful cause who made Michele's struggles more bearable and supported her through a very difficult time.

We have arranged this challenge with the support of our local leisure centre and will be completing it within current COVID rules. This will mean we will be swimming for a 1 hour slot, running for 1 hour in the gym then cycling outside for 1 hour! 

Please donate, even the smallest of amounts helps.

Thank you,

Anna& Karl

I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support.n 2015 i was diagnosed with a rare heart condition know as Catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (CPVT), basically meaning i have a hole in my heart.This is a rare heart condition which is characterised by an abnormal heart rhythm (arrhythmia), this is caused by an increase in heart rate in response to physical activity or emotional stress, CPVT cause be triggered by an abnormally fast heartbeat called ventricular tachycardia, through the years that i had spent going in and out of hospital getting blood tests for all different things like genetic testing to see the blood line of heart issues had any link to my condition all they found back then was that it was a rare condition and that i was the 3rd person in the UK alone to be diagnosed with the condition, after loads of tests and having cameras put down my throat for research they were unable to find anything to help me treat the issue so they sent me away telling me I could never do sports or work basically putting me on the sick for life, but with great fight i decided that I wasn’t going to give up their by listening to doctors I went out got a job and studied at college for 6 years , today in 2020 I haven’t had any issues with my heart but this issue still runs inside me and other people out there so I have decided that i want use my Platform on @twitch and help raise money for the British Heart Foundation, to help raise awareness so that one day we can find a cure for heart conditions like CPVT ,

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:
It is with great sadness that Andrew & I share the news that our father passed away on 27 October 2020.

As you may know he was diagnosed with cancer a few years ago.

Thankfully he experienced almost no symptoms or side effects from this or the treatment which has been a huge relief to us all. Early in the year, the doctors ran out of treatment options and in April he collapsed suddenly. Since then he’s been at home and Andrew and I have been  looking after him along with a fantastic team of carers. We’ve had many  uplifting conversations with him during this time about how much he  enjoyed his childhood, friendships, his time in the army, his career and retirement.

The ending was as peaceful as we could possibly have hoped for. Andrew and I were both with him, holding his hands, in his own home just as he wanted. The help we’ve had this last week from the carers, St.  Christopher’s Hospice, Marie Curie and the district nurses has been  truly amazing, giving him a dignified, peaceful and painless end that we were worried he wouldn’t have. We've chosen Marie Curie as Dad was already a benefactor of St. Christopher's.

Over the last few months, Andrew & I have been reflecting on what an outstanding father he has been – the perfect Dad. He adored his seven grandchildren and was immensely proud of them all. His devotion and care for our mother, who has advanced dementia, in recent years is a model of marriage that will remain with us.

story:
We're here to support people with serious illnesses in the Newcastle area to have the best quality of life possible, whatever that might mean for them.

Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by over 100 volunteers, who play a vital role in the running of the hospice. 

Some people stay in our 20-bed in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish.

Our day therapy unit offers outpatient clinics and a wide range of activities and therapies, including baking, art therapy and relaxation. 

We also provide support for carers and families, including our social work team who provide emotional and practical advice. Our chaplain is here to provide spiritual care to patients and their loved ones.

Thank you for supporting us, and helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in the Newcastle area get the care and support they need.

story:
We are the Congleton Fundraising branch of the RNLI and
this year many of our collections and events have been cancelled.

Unfortunately our annual Fish Supper event  had to be cancelled this year due to Coronavirus as well as our usual Flag Day. The RNLI has managed to maintain a 24/7 service every day since lockdown began. Our brave crews and lifeguards have still been launching and saving people in trouble at the coast, even though we haven’t been able to fundraise. 

So many of our crew’s family dinners are interrupted by calls to rescue those in need.

They’re giving everything they can, will you give what you can?

Everybody is welcome to our virtual fish supper this October and please give as much or as little as you can or even the cost of a fish supper to
keep our crews safe and equipped.

story:
Hi, 

My name's Orla and I will be running the Manchester Marathon 2021 to support the work of WWF and bring attention to human activity and how we're destroying the planet.

We as humans impact the physical environment in various ways: pollution, burning fossil fuels, deforestation, waste and overpopulation. Changes like these have triggered climate change, soil erosion, poor air quality, wildlife extinction and ecosystem destruction. 

WWF is the world's leading independent conservation organisation who retain the mission to create a world where humans and wildlife can thrive together.  

Finding ways to help transform the future of our wildlife, rivers, forests and seas; pushing for a reduction in carbon emissions to avoid catastrophic climate change and pressing for measures to help people live sustainably, within the means of our planet is no simple task, therefore, it has become essential now more than ever to reverse environmental degradation.

"We are the first generation to know that we are destroying the world. And we could be the last to do anything about it. It's time to decide. Are you for your world or against it?" 

https://www.youtube.com/user/WWFunitedkingdom

Together we can build a future where people and nature can prosper together.

Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

Your support is much appreciated.

story: "Spending time in nature has been found to help with mental health problems including anxiety and depression." - Mind.org.uk. Nature, wildlife and the outdoors is not only good for us but ESSENTIAL to our mental health. However, you might notice there's less wildlife than there used to be. Thats because half of all UK species are in decline - we're losing our precious red squirrels, hedgehogs and birds at an alarming rate, not to mention that the our Living Planet Report shows a staggering 68% decline in wildlife populations globally. By donating to The Big Winter Wander, you, your friends and family can reconnect with our country's beautiful wildlife and help protect it. The funds you raise will help WWF's campaign to protect wildlife here, and around the world. Nature has been there to offer us comfort during difficult times, and now its our time to give back. eventName: Baking without Borders - Eat cake, do good.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I will be selling delicious things that I bake and donating all profits to MSF.  Each time I sell a cake, I will donate to this page so that everyone can see how eating delicious home-baked cakes and biscuits can also do good.  I am doing this as part of my Duke of Edinburgh Bronze Award. 

If you would like to donate directly to MSF on this page, then feel free!  No need to have cake, if don't want to, or if you aren't in my local area.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.



This event is the best starting point for anyone interested in the work of MSF. there are two parts:

We will be doing a little introduction into MSFs work and some of it’s key principles and organisational structure. We will also Highlight some of the work that FoMSF has done!

In the second part, we will introduce a scenario game called “the Malnutrition game” designed by an MSF field worker in South Sudan. This is a great opportunity for some interaction and insight in what it means to be an MSF field worker!

We welcome anyone who is interested to join!

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Starting on the 17th of October, I will be running 100 miles over 30 days to raise money for WaterAid. Any donations, no matter how big or small, will be greatly appreciated.


A Statement From WaterAid

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.
